name: Andrew Head
content: Andrew Head Andrew Head | Andrew is an Assistant Professor of computer science at the University of Pennsylvania. He studies the use of computers as comprehension aids for some of the most complex information artifacts, like code, science papers, medical notes, and mechanized proofs. Andrew Head Assistant Professor @ UPenn Computer Science head@seas.upenn.edu Follow my updates on LinkedIn Areas of interest: Human-computer interaction Â· Programming Â· Reading. Welcome to my home page! I am Andrew Head, an assistant professor at the University of Pennsylvania. My group specializes in developing technology for interactive reading and reasoning. My current goals are to: Help scientists get more out of their readings in less time Make math notation everywhere inviting and understandable Help programmers comprehend code using AI Accelerate programmers in writing, maintaining, and understanding proofs of correctness about their programs Our projects follow a systems-centric HCI approach. We do in-depth user studies to understand what people need from their tools. Then, we build working interactive systems, imbuing them with powerful new interaction design ideas. We publish our work at ACM CHI and UIST, and other venues focused on information presentation and programming support. ðŸ‘¥ Â Our group I advise Ph.D. students Alyssa Hwang, Litao Yan, Hita Kambhamettu, Jeff Tao, Jessica Shi, and Xiaorui Liu. I co-lead our Penn Human-Computer Interaction (Penn HCI) alongside DanaÃ© Metaxa. Our group works closely with Benjamin Pierce from PLClub and Chris Callison-Burch from PennNLP. I am also a faculty affiliate for Pennâ€™s MindCORE center. Prospective Ph.D. applicants: I will not be taking on incoming Ph.D. students in fall 2026. Penn master's and bachelor's students: If you want to do research with our group, take Penn's class in human-computer interactionâ€”CIS 4120/5120â€”and then apply to do research with our group here. You may also want to keep an eye out for special topics courses (7000-level) that I and Professor Metaxa teach, which frequently offer hands-on research experiences. ðŸ“° Â Our latest news October 2025: Litao Yan presented his paper on Trailblazer at UIST '25. The paper describes the design and evaluation of a tool for answering developer questions with agent-discovered program traces. July 2025: Congratulations Harry Goldstein, Penn HCI alum, on receiving one of SIGPLAN's two oustanding dissertation awards. Congratulations as well on beginning your assistant professor position at UBuffalo. March 2025: Two projects from our group will appear at CHI! The first is Jeffrey Tao's Freeform editor for embellishing math notation with explanations, accepted as a full paper. The second is Hita Kambhamettu's study of the effect of source-summary links on the reading of AI-generated text, which will appear as late-breaking work. February 2025: Jessica Shi's QED in Context will appear in OOPSLA '25. The paper highlights strategies and obstacles proof assistant users face with their tools. Read the pre-print here. September 2024: This semester, I am teaching a new research seminar on Interactive Reading. Our goal is to develop technology that deepens, accelerates, and enlivens reading. Check out the course teaser and syllabus. August 2024: Harry Goldstein has had a paper accepted to UIST '24 on Tyche, a in-editor UI that helps programmers understand the comprehensiveness of their property-based tests.
